rev.comment: Why does everything must the labeled as a "controversy"?!?! it is very unhelful
rev.diff:
Line 24: Line 24:
Fail Blog's first book, ''Fail Nation: A Visual Romp Through the World of Epic Fails'' (ISBN 9780061833991), was released on October 6, 2009.<ref>[http://failblog.org/2009/07/21/pre-order-your-copy-of-fail-nation/ Pre-order Your Copy of FAIL Nation], Failblog.org, Jul. 21, 2009, Retrieved Sept. 9, 2009</ref>
Fail Blog's first book, ''Fail Nation: A Visual Romp Through the World of Epic Fails'' (ISBN 9780061833991), was released on October 6, 2009.<ref>[http://failblog.org/2009/07/21/pre-order-your-copy-of-fail-nation/ Pre-order Your Copy of FAIL Nation], Failblog.org, Jul. 21, 2009, Retrieved Sept. 9, 2009</ref>
â
==Controversies==
+
==Issues==
In July 2009, Fail Blog received an email from [[Guinness World Records]] requesting that a Fail Blog entry, regarding the Guinness record webpage for "Most Individuals Killed in A Terrorist Attack" having a "Break this record" link, have the screenshot of the webpage removed because it contained the [[trademark]]ed Guinness World Records [[logo]]. Fail Blog promptly complied with the removal of the image, replacing it by an edited version with all notable references to Guinness record webpage blurred out, and posted an entry on the incident, with what C-Net described as a "hilarious response complete with a [[Rick Roll]] at the end".<ref>[http://failblog.org/2009/07/13/omg-u-fail-so-hard/ OMG YOU FAIL SO HARD], Failblog.org, Jul. 13, 2009, Retrieved Sept. 9, 2009</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.cnet.com/8301-13952_1-10286349-81.html| title=The 404 381: Where we gotta stay positive| publisher=''[[CNET_Networks|CNET News]]'' | date=July 14, 2009 | accessdate=Sept. 9, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.techcrunch.com/2009/07/13/guinness-world-records-reaches-new-levels-of-fail/| title=Guinness World Records Reaches New Levels Of Fail| publisher=''[[TechCrunch]]'' | date=July 13, 2009 | accessdate=Sept. 9, 2009}}</ref>
In July 2009, Fail Blog received an email from [[Guinness World Records]] requesting that a Fail Blog entry, regarding the Guinness record webpage for "Most Individuals Killed in A Terrorist Attack" having a "Break this record" link, have the screenshot of the webpage removed because it contained the [[trademark]]ed Guinness World Records [[logo]]. Fail Blog promptly complied with the removal of the image, replacing it by an edited version with all notable references to Guinness record webpage blurred out, and posted an entry on the incident, with what C-Net described as a "hilarious response complete with a [[Rick Roll]] at the end".<ref>[http://failblog.org/2009/07/13/omg-u-fail-so-hard/ OMG YOU FAIL SO HARD], Failblog.org, Jul. 13, 2009, Retrieved Sept. 9, 2009</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.cnet.com/8301-13952_1-10286349-81.html| title=The 404 381: Where we gotta stay positive| publisher=''[[CNET_Networks|CNET News]]'' | date=July 14, 2009 | accessdate=Sept. 9, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.techcrunch.com/2009/07/13/guinness-world-records-reaches-new-levels-of-fail/| title=Guinness World Records Reaches New Levels Of Fail| publisher=''[[TechCrunch]]'' | date=July 13, 2009 | accessdate=Sept. 9, 2009}}</ref>
